newsitem.title: UK: UK businesses split on EMU - CBI survey.
newsitem.headline: UK businesses split on EMU - CBI survey.

text.p: UK companies are split over participation in the single European currency, a survey by the Confederation of British Industry (CBI) showed.

Fifty-six percent of companies support the principle of the UK participating in European economic and monetary union (EMU), while 30 percent are opposed, the CBI said in a statement released at the start of its annual conference on Sunday.

Asked what decisions Britain should make now on EMU participation, 28 percent of companies polled favoured a clear commmitment to entry in 1999. A further 17 percent were in favour of joining, either in 1999 or later.
Sixteen percent were against membership in 1999, but wanted to keep open the option of membership at a later stage. Seven percent said the wanted the UK to reject EMU membership.
The survey was conducted by market research company MORI on behalf of the CBI and the British Chambers of Commerce. Out of a total of 5,000 firms contacted, 1,691 replied.
